greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Decimal expansion of P_{3,2}(9) = Sum 1/p^9 over primes == 2 (mod 3).
comment: The prime zeta modulo function P_{m,r}(s) = Sum_{primes p == r (mod m)} 1/p^s generalizes the prime zeta function P(s) = Sum_{primes p} 1/p^s.
link: Jean-François Alcover, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1005
R. J. Mathar, Table of Dirichlet L-series and Prime Zeta Modulo Functions for Small Moduli, arXiv:1008.2547 [math.NT], 2010-2015, value P(m=3, n=2, s=9), p. 21.
OEIS index to entries related to the (prime) zeta function.
mathematica: PrimeZeta31[s_, nmax_] := PrimeZeta31[s, nmax] = Sum[Module[{t}, t = s + 2 n*s; MoebiusMu[2 n + 1] ((1/(4 n + 2)) (-Log[1 + 2^t] - Log[1 + 3^t] + Log[Zeta[t]] - Log[Zeta[2 t]] + Log[Zeta[t, 1/6] - Zeta[t, 5/6]]))], {n, 0, nmax}] // N[#, digits + 5] &;
While[Abs[PrimeZeta31[9, nmax] - PrimeZeta31[9, nmax - dnmax]] > 10^-(digits + 5), Print["nmax = ", nmax]; nmax += dnmax];
Join[{0, 0}, RealDigits[PrimeZeta32[9], 10, digits][[1]] ] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, May 07 2021, after _M. F. Hasler_'s PARI code *)
program: (PARI) A343619_upto(N=100)={localprec(N+5); digits((PrimeZeta32(9)+1)\.1^N)[^1]} \\ see A343612 for the function PrimeZeta32
xref: Cf. A343629 (for primes 3k+1), A086039 (for primes 4k+1), A085998 (for primes 4k+3).
results.author: _M. F. Hasler_, Apr 25 2021
